column1: I had often wondered what became of this highly interesting young woman
column2: and when I began to write "The White Morning" she popped into my mind. I believe she could be a leader of some kind if she chose. Perhaps she is. The cases could be multiplied indefinitely. The Erkels and Mimi Brandt are drawn
column4: almost photographically. "Heloise" finally married a Scot and went with him to his own country
column5: but her sisters were dragging out their tragic lives when I left Munich. A few days ago I met a highly intelligent American woman of German blood who
column7: used to visit her relatives in Germany every year. I told her that I had written this story and she agreed with me that it was on the cards the women would instigate a revolution. "Never
column8: she said, in any country have I known such discontent among women
column9: heard so many bitter confidences. Their feelings against their fathers or husbands were the more intense and violent because they dared not speak out like English or American women."
